The presence of mutations could disrupt the operon, but if there are wild-type alleles present, maybe those can compensate, leading to some form of redundancy. Now, the scenario says that some mutations are bypassed because of partial diploids. Since wild-type alleles are dominant, any disruption caused by mutations might not completely prevent the operon from working. If the operon is induced (lactose present), the repressor should bind, preventing transcription. As a consequence, some mutations can be bypassedin terms of their disruption of theoperonby productionof the partial diploids with wild-type alleles at the sitesof mutation. In each case the wild-type allele is dominant to its mutant homologue. A. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Inducible, (c) No production of enzymes

B. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) No production of enzymes

C. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) Inducible, (c) Constitutive synthesis

D. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) Inducible

E. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Inducible

F. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Inducible, (c) Constitutive synthesis

G. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Inducible

H. (a) Inducible, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Constitutive synthesis

I. (a) Inducible, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) No production of enzymes

J. (a) Inducible, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) Inducible

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
